synsets.definition: a query language for APIs that allows clients to request exactly the data they need in a single request
examples: Define your API schema in GraphQL

synsets.definition: a high-performance RPC framework using Protocol Buffers for efficient binary serialization and HTTP/2 for transport
examples: gRPC is ideal for microservice communication

synsets.definition: a protocol providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection for real-time data exchange
examples: WebSocket connections stay open for bidirectional messaging

synsets.definition: Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for APIs using HTTP methods to operate on resources
examples: REST APIs use standard HTTP verbs
Design RESTful endpoints for your resources

synsets.definition: an open standard for access delegation, allowing users to grant third-party access to resources without sharing credentials
JSON Web Token, a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between parties
examples: JWTs are used for stateless authentication
Decode the JWT to verify the user

synsets.definition: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing, a mechanism that allows web pages to make requests to domains other than their origin
examples: Configure CORS headers to allow API access

synsets.definition: Cross-Site Request Forgery, an attack that tricks users into executing unwanted actions on authenticated sites
OpenID Connect, an identity layer built on top of OAuth 2.0 for authentication and identity verification
a distributed event streaming platform for high-throughput, fault-tolerant publish-subscribe messaging
examples: Kafka handles millions of events per second

synsets.definition: an open-source message broker implementing AMQP protocol for reliable message queuing
Server-Sent Events, a standard for servers to push updates to clients over HTTP connections
examples: SSE is simpler than WebSockets for one-way streaming

synsets.definition: a user-defined HTTP callback triggered by specific events, enabling real-time notifications between services
examples: Configure a webhook to receive payment notifications
Webhooks push data when events occur

synsets.definition: a specification for describing REST APIs in a machine-readable format, enabling documentation and code generation
examples: Generate client SDKs from OpenAPI specs

synsets.definition: a technique to control the number of requests a client can make to an API within a time period
examples: Implement rate limiting to prevent abuse

synsets.definition: a unique identifier used to authenticate requests to an API, simpler than OAuth for machine-to-machine auth
examples: Include the API key in request headers

synsets.definition: the practice of dividing API responses into pages to manage large result sets efficiently
a property where multiple identical requests have the same effect as a single request, ensuring safe retries
examples: Use idempotency keys for payment APIs

synsets.definition: Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State, a REST constraint where responses include links to related resources
examples: Include navigation links in API responses

synsets.definition: Protocol Buffers, Google's language-neutral binary serialization format for structured data
examples: Protobuf is more efficient than JSON

synsets.definition: an API platform for building, testing, and documenting APIs with collaborative features
examples: Share Postman collections with your team

synsets.definition: an open-source API client for REST, GraphQL, and gRPC testing with environment management
a user-friendly command-line HTTP client with intuitive syntax and JSON support
examples: HTTPie makes CLI API testing easier
Use http command instead of curl

synsets.definition: HTTP Basic Authentication, a simple authentication scheme sending username and password with each request
examples: Basic auth is simple but less secure

synsets.definition: an authentication token sent in the Authorization header to authenticate API requests
examples: Include the bearer token in the Authorization header
Bearer tokens grant access to protected resources

synsets.definition: strategies for managing API changes over time while maintaining backward compatibility
a design pattern that prevents cascading failures by stopping requests to failing services
examples: Circuit breakers protect against service failures
Open the circuit breaker after repeated failures

synsets.definition: a resilience pattern that automatically retries failed requests with exponential backoff
a major revision of HTTP enabling multiplexed streams, header compression, and server push
the next major version of HTTP using QUIC instead of TCP for improved performance and reliability
examples: HTTP/3 handles packet loss better than HTTP/2
